nodes.label: Computational Science
nodes.title: Computational Science
nodes.description: Computational Science:

nodes.label: Introduction
nodes.title: Introduction
nodes.description: Introduction:

nodes.label: The 3rd pillar of science
nodes.title: The 3rd pillar of science
nodes.description: The 3rd pillar of science: The 3rd pillar of science: Refers to computer simulation as a foundational tool in scientific inquiry, alongside theory and experimentation.

nodes.label: System, experiment, model, simulation
nodes.title: System, experiment, model, simulation
nodes.description: System, experiment, model, simulation: System, experiment, model, simulation: Concepts central to the scientific process, where systems are studied through experiments, modeled, and simulated to gain insights.

nodes.label: Validation and verification
nodes.title: Validation and verification
nodes.description: Validation and verification: Validation and verification: Processes for ensuring that simulation models accurately represent the real-world systems they aim to simulate.

nodes.label: Types of models
nodes.title: Types of models
nodes.description: Types of models: Types of models: Includes mathematical models, physical models, conceptual models, and computational models, each serving different purposes in scientific inquiry and engineering.

nodes.label: Cellular Automata
nodes.title: Cellular Automata
nodes.description: Cellular Automata:

nodes.label: Cellular Automata Introduction
nodes.title: Cellular Automata Introduction
nodes.description: Cellular Automata Introduction: Cellular Automata Introduction: A computational model consisting of a grid of cells, each in a certain state, with their states evolving over discrete time steps based on predefined rules.

nodes.label: Wolfram classification
nodes.title: Wolfram classification
nodes.description: Wolfram classification: Wolfram classification: Stephen Wolfram's classification of cellular automata into four classes based on their behavior, ranging from simple and predictable to complex and unpredictable.

nodes.label: Transients and cycles
nodes.title: Transients and cycles
nodes.description: Transients and cycles: Transients and cycles: Temporary states that occur during the evolution of cellular automata before reaching a stable configuration or periodic behavior.

nodes.label: CA quantify complexity
nodes.title: CA quantify complexity
nodes.description: CA quantify complexity: CA quantify complexity: Cellular Automata (CA) quantify complexity through various measures such as entropy, fractal dimension, and computational universality.

nodes.label: Langton parameter
nodes.title: Langton parameter
nodes.description: Langton parameter: Langton parameter: Introduced by Chris Langton, it quantifies the behavior of CA and is calculated as the ratio of the number of 1s in the CA rule table to the total number of entries in the table.

nodes.label: Complexity measures
nodes.title: Complexity measures
nodes.description: Complexity measures: Complexity measures: These include metrics such as entropy, which measures the randomness or uncertainty in the system, and fractal dimension, which characterizes the irregularity and self-similarity of CA patterns.

nodes.label: 2-dimensional CA and Game of Life
nodes.title: 2-dimensional CA and Game of Life
nodes.description: 2-dimensional CA and Game of Life:

nodes.label: 2-dimensional CA
nodes.title: 2-dimensional CA
nodes.description: 2-dimensional CA: 2-dimensional CA: Cellular Automata (CA) extended to two dimensions, where each cell has neighbors in a grid-like structure, allowing for more complex patterns and behavior to emerge.

nodes.label: Game of Life
nodes.title: Game of Life
nodes.description: Game of Life: Game of Life: A famous example of a 2-dimensional CA devised by John Conway, where cells in a grid evolve based on simple rules related to the number of neighboring live cells.

nodes.label: Universal computation
nodes.title: Universal computation
nodes.description: Universal computation: Universal computation: Game of Life has been shown to be Turing complete, meaning it can simulate any algorithmic process and perform any computation that a Turing machine can.

nodes.label: CA-based models, Fire, traffic
nodes.title: CA-based models, Fire, traffic
nodes.description: CA-based models, Fire, traffic:

nodes.label: Forest fire
nodes.title: Forest fire
nodes.description: Forest fire: Forest fire: CA models used to simulate the spread and behavior of forest fires, where each cell represents a part of the forest, and rules dictate how fires spread based on factors like neighboring trees and wind direction.

nodes.label: Lattice gas
nodes.title: Lattice gas
nodes.description: Lattice gas: Lattice gas: A CA model used to simulate fluid dynamics and gas behavior, where cells represent particles in a lattice and rules govern their movement and interactions.

nodes.label: Traffic flow
nodes.title: Traffic flow
nodes.description: Traffic flow: Traffic flow: CA models used to simulate vehicular traffic, where cells represent sections of road and rules dictate vehicle movement and behavior based on factors like speed limits, congestion, and driver behavior.

nodes.label: Mean-field theory and Voting model
nodes.title: Mean-field theory and Voting model
nodes.description: Mean-field theory and Voting model:

nodes.label: Mean-field theory
nodes.title: Mean-field theory
nodes.description: Mean-field theory: Mean-field theory: A mathematical approach used to study large systems of interacting elements by approximating their behavior through statistical averages, assuming each element interacts with the "field" created by all others.

nodes.label: 2D discrete CA-based
nodes.title: 2D discrete CA-based
nodes.description: 2D discrete CA-based: 2D discrete CA-based: Cellular automata models operating in two-dimensional space, where each cell's state evolves over time based on the states of its neighboring cells according to predefined rules.

nodes.label: 0D continuous ODE
nodes.title: 0D continuous ODE
nodes.description: 0D continuous ODE: 0D continuous ODE: A zero-dimensional model represented by continuous ordinary differential equations, typically used to describe systems where variables change continuously over time without spatial considerations.

nodes.label: Predator-prey model
nodes.title: Predator-prey model
nodes.description: Predator-prey model: Predator-prey model: A mathematical model used to describe the dynamics of predator and prey populations in ecology, often represented by a system of coupled differential equations or as a cellular automaton.

nodes.label: Voting model
nodes.title: Voting model
nodes.description: Voting model: Voting model: A model used to study opinion dynamics, where individuals update their opinions based on the opinions of their neighbors, often represented as a cellular automaton or a stochastic process.

nodes.label: Game theory and Genetic Algorithms
nodes.title: Game theory and Genetic Algorithms
nodes.description: Game theory and Genetic Algorithms:

nodes.label: Strategic interdependent behavior
nodes.title: Strategic interdependent behavior
nodes.description: Strategic interdependent behavior: Strategic interdependent behavior: Analyzing decisions made by multiple actors, where each actor's choice depends on the choices made by others, leading to strategic interactions.

nodes.label: Parallel scenarios
nodes.title: Parallel scenarios
nodes.description: Parallel scenarios: Parallel scenarios: Instances where multiple independent scenarios or games are analyzed simultaneously, allowing for comparisons or interactions between them.

nodes.label: Payoff tables
nodes.title: Payoff tables
nodes.description: Payoff tables: Payoff tables: Tables used in game theory to represent the payoffs or outcomes associated with different strategies chosen by players in a game.

nodes.label: Strict dominance and Nash equilibria
nodes.title: Strict dominance and Nash equilibria
nodes.description: Strict dominance and Nash equilibria: Strict dominance and Nash equilibria: Concepts in game theory where a strategy strictly dominates another if it always yields a higher payoff regardless of opponents' choices, and Nash equilibria are sets of strategies where no player can unilaterally improve their payoff.

nodes.label: Mixed strategy
nodes.title: Mixed strategy
nodes.description: Mixed strategy: Mixed strategy: A strategy where a player randomly selects from among several pure strategies according to specified probabilities.

nodes.label: Iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma
nodes.title: Iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma
nodes.description: Iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma: Iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma: A version of the Prisoner's Dilemma game where players repeatedly interact and have the opportunity to learn from past interactions, leading to more complex strategies.

nodes.label: model cooperation/competition
nodes.title: model cooperation/competition
nodes.description: model cooperation/competition: Model cooperation/competition: Studying how cooperation and competition emerge among agents in a system, often modeled using game theory principles.

nodes.label: Genetic algorithms
nodes.title: Genetic algorithms
nodes.description: Genetic algorithms: Genetic algorithms: Optimization algorithms inspired by the process of natural selection and evolution, where solutions to a problem are represented as individuals in a population and undergo selection, crossover, and mutation to evolve toward better solutions over generations.

nodes.label: CA analytics
nodes.title: CA analytics
nodes.description: CA analytics:

nodes.label: Totalistic
nodes.title: Totalistic
nodes.description: Totalistic: Totalistic: A type of cellular automaton (CA) rule where the next state of a cell depends only on the total sum of states of neighboring cells, rather than the specific configuration of neighboring cells.

nodes.label: Probabilistic
nodes.title: Probabilistic
nodes.description: Probabilistic: Probabilistic: Cellular automaton rules where the state transitions of cells are determined by probabilities rather than deterministic rules, allowing for randomness in the evolution of the system.

nodes.label: Additive
nodes.title: Additive
nodes.description: Additive: Additive: CA rules where the new state of a cell is determined by adding the states of neighboring cells, often used in continuous CA models.

nodes.label: Reversible
nodes.title: Reversible
nodes.description: Reversible: Reversible: Cellular automaton rules that allow for the reversal of time, meaning that given a future state, the past state can be uniquely determined, facilitating bijective mappings between states.

nodes.label: Ergodic
nodes.title: Ergodic
nodes.description: Ergodic: Ergodic: A property of CA systems where, over time, the system visits all possible states with nonzero probability, indicating that the system explores its state space thoroughly.

nodes.label: Complex Networks and Graph theory
nodes.title: Complex Networks and Graph theory
nodes.description: Complex Networks and Graph theory:

nodes.label: Complex networks
nodes.title: Complex networks
nodes.description: Complex networks: Complex networks: Networks characterized by non-trivial topological features, such as high clustering, small-world properties, and scale-free degree distributions.

nodes.label: Complex systems
nodes.title: Complex systems
nodes.description: Complex systems: Complex systems: Systems composed of interconnected elements that exhibit emergent behaviors and properties arising from interactions between these elements.

nodes.label: Network
nodes.title: Network
nodes.description: Network: Network: A structure comprising nodes (or vertices) connected by edges (or links), representing relationships or interactions between entities.

nodes.label: The role of networks
nodes.title: The role of networks
nodes.description: The role of networks: The role of networks: Networks serve as frameworks for representing and analyzing relationships between various entities, facilitating the study of complex systems in diverse domains.

nodes.label: The life of networks
nodes.title: The life of networks
nodes.description: The life of networks: The life of networks: Networks evolve over time through processes such as growth, adaptation, and decay, leading to changes in their structure, dynamics, and functionality.

nodes.label: Network science
nodes.title: Network science
nodes.description: Network science: Network science: An interdisciplinary field that studies the structure, dynamics, and function of complex networks, drawing from mathematics, physics, computer science, and other disciplines.

nodes.label: Impact of network science
nodes.title: Impact of network science
nodes.description: Impact of network science: Impact of network science: Network science has profound implications across various domains, including biology, sociology, technology, and ecology, enabling insights into phenomena such as epidemics, social behavior, information flow, and organizational dynamics.

nodes.label: Graph
nodes.title: Graph
nodes.description: Graph:

nodes.label: A proper representation
nodes.title: A proper representation
nodes.description: A proper representation: A proper representation: Graphs are mathematical structures comprising vertices (nodes) and edges (links) that represent relationships between pairs of vertices.

nodes.label: Measures
nodes.title: Measures
nodes.description: Measures: Measures: Graph measures quantify various properties of graphs, such as the number of vertices, edges, and paths, as well as metrics related to connectivity, centrality, and clustering.

nodes.label: Graphology
nodes.title: Graphology
nodes.description: Graphology: Graphology: The study of graphs, including their structure, properties, and behaviors, often applied in fields such as network science and social network analysis.

nodes.label: Pathology
nodes.title: Pathology
nodes.description: Pathology: Pathology: The study of paths in graphs, focusing on properties such as shortest paths, cycles, and connectivity, with applications in transportation, communication, and optimization.

nodes.label: Degree distribution
nodes.title: Degree distribution
nodes.description: Degree distribution: Degree distribution: A statistical measure describing the distribution of degrees (number of connections) among vertices in a graph, providing insights into its topology and connectivity patterns.

nodes.label: Types of Networks
nodes.title: Types of Networks
nodes.description: Types of Networks: Types of Networks: Various models categorize networks based on their structural properties and characteristics, including regular lattices, random networks, small-world networks, and scale-free networks.

nodes.label: Regular lattice
nodes.title: Regular lattice
nodes.description: Regular lattice: Regular lattice: A type of network characterized by a regular, repeating geometric structure, where each node is connected to its nearest neighbors according to a predefined pattern.

nodes.label: Random Networks
nodes.title: Random Networks
nodes.description: Random Networks: Random Networks: Networks where edges are randomly distributed between vertices, leading to a homogeneous degree distribution and properties resembling those of a random graph.

nodes.label: Watts-Strogatz model
nodes.title: Watts-Strogatz model
nodes.description: Watts-Strogatz model: Watts-Strogatz model: A model for generating small-world networks, characterized by high clustering and short average path lengths, proposed by Duncan Watts and Steven Strogatz in 1998.

nodes.label: Scale-Free Networks
nodes.title: Scale-Free Networks
nodes.description: Scale-Free Networks: Scale-Free Networks: Networks where the degree distribution follows a power-law distribution, meaning that a few nodes (hubs) have a disproportionately high number of connections compared to the majority of nodes.
